title: 114_s2327
content: The "Foster EITC Act of 2015" is the short title of the Act. It includes a permanent extension of modifications to the Earned Income Tax Credit. Increase in Credit Percentage for Families With 3 or More Children under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986, where the credit percentage is increased from 40 to 45 for eligible individuals with 3 or more qualifying children. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to increase the credit percentage from 40 to 45 for eligible individuals with 3 or more qualifying children. Additionally, the income threshold for joint returns is raised from $3,000 to $5,000, with inflation adjustments made for the calendar year 2008. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to increase the credit percentage for eligible individuals with 3 or more qualifying children. Section 32(b) is amended by striking paragraph (3). The amendments apply to taxable years beginning after December 31, 2014. The Earned Income Tax Credit is being strengthened by increasing the credit percentage for eligible individuals with 3 or more qualifying children. The Earned Income Tax Credit is being enhanced by raising the credit amounts for individuals with no qualifying children. The table in the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to increase the credit from $4,220 to $8,820 and from $5,280 to $10,425. Inflation adjustments are also made to further improve the credit. The table in section 32(b)(1)(A) of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to increase the credit amounts for individuals with no children to $8,820 and $10,425 for calendar year 2011. The table in section 32(b)(1)(A) of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to increase credit amounts for individuals with no children to $8,820 and $10,425 for calendar year 2011. Additionally, the eligibility age for certain childless individuals and youth formerly in foster care is lowered to age 21 (or age 18 for youth formerly in foster care). The Internal Revenue Code is amended to increase credit amounts for individuals with no children and lower the eligibility age for certain childless individuals and youth formerly in foster care to age 21 (or age 18 for youth formerly in foster care). Additionally, a new provision defines "youth formerly in foster care" as an individual who was in foster care on or after the age of 16. Subchapter A of chapter 61 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to include a new section after section 6050W. "New section 6050X requires returns related to youth in foster care." The new section 6050X mandates reporting by State, local, or tribal agencies on individuals in foster care aged 16 and above. The new section 6050X requires reporting by State, local, or tribal agencies on individuals in foster care aged 16 and above. An individual who has made a return as described in the paragraph is not required to make a return for any subsequent calendar year. The return must be in the form prescribed by the Secretary and include the name, date of birth, and TIN of each individual mentioned in subsection (a)(1), along with their assigned identification number for statewide or tribal purposes. The new section 6050X requires reporting by State, local, or tribal agencies on individuals in foster care aged 16 and above. The return must include the name, date of birth, and TIN of each individual mentioned in subsection (a)(1), along with their assigned identification number for statewide or tribal purposes. Additionally, individuals must be furnished with a written statement containing the name, address, and phone number of the person required to make the return. The written statement required under section 6050X must include the name, address, and phone number of the person responsible for making the return, along with the necessary information for the individual mentioned in the return. The IRS code is amended to include a new clause related to returns for youth in foster care. Additionally, a conforming amendment is made to the table of sections. The IRS code is amended to include returns for youth in foster care, effective for taxable years after December 31, 2014. Additionally, there is a section simplifying the Earned Income Tax Credit. The IRS code is amended to include a modification of the Abandoned Spouse Rule for married individuals living apart with a qualifying child for more than half of the taxable year. The IRS code is amended to modify the Abandoned Spouse Rule for married individuals living apart with a qualifying child for more than half of the taxable year, stating that they shall not be considered as married under certain conditions. The IRS code is amended to simplify rules regarding the presence of a qualifying child for the tax credit for workers. The IRS code is amended to allow taxpayers to claim a credit for a worker without a qualifying child if the child is claimed by another family member. For a taxable year, if an individual is claimed as a qualifying child by one eligible individual, any other eligible individual not making such a claim can be considered eligible without a qualifying child for the tax credit. If a child is claimed as a qualifying child by one eligible individual, no other custodial parent who does not claim the child can be considered eligible for the tax credit without a qualifying child for that year. The tax credit for a worker without a qualifying child is available to taxpayers if their qualifying children do not have a valid social security number. This amendment affects individuals with qualifying children who are not considered for the tax credit due to certain reasons. The amendments made by this section allow individuals without qualifying children to be considered eligible for the tax credit, effective for taxable years starting after December 31, 2014.
